title: Large Bowel Obstruction from Colon Cancer
diagnosis_topic: Obstruction of the large intestine due to malignancy
setup_script: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive abdominal distension, obstipation and weight loss over two weeks. He reports intermittent cramping pain and nausea.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.3 C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs abdominal and rectal exam
dynamic_flow.reply: Distended tympanitic abdomen, hyperactive bowel sounds; empty rectal vault; no obvious mass on digital rectal exam.
Mild leukocytosis, electrolyte disturbances (hyponatremia), and anemia (hemoglobin 10 g/dL).
Dilated colon with haustral markings; cecum 9 cm diameter; no free air.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Transition point at sigmoid colon with apple-core lesion; proximal colon markedly dilated; no perforation.
IV fluids, NPO, nasogastric tube for decompression and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery and gastroenterology
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopic stent placement as a bridge to surgery for left-sided obstruction; right-sided lesions typically require immediate surgery (right hemicolectomy).
Emergent surgery with resection and either primary anastomosis or colostomy depending on contamination and patient factors.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders colonoscopy biopsy of the lesion
dynamic_flow.reply: Confirms adenocarcinoma; staging CT chest for metastases.
Cecal perforation and feculent peritonitis may develop.
Temporary diverting stoma may be required; plan adjuvant chemotherapy based on stage.
Explain stenting vs. surgery, potential need for stoma and oncologic follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of large bowel obstruction and differentiation of causes
Resuscitation and decompression of the obstructed colon
Decision-making between stent placement and emergent surgery
Prevention of perforation through timely intervention
